author: thezim
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

```bash
$ which powershell
/usr/local/bin/powershell
$ alias wh='which'
$ wh powershell
/usr/local/bin/powershell
$ powershell 
PowerShell v6.0.0-beta.8
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
```
```powershell
PS > which powershell                                                                                               
/usr/local/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-beta.8/powershell
PS > wh powershell                                                                                                  
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
PS /Users/greg/temp> wh powershell
/usr/local/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-beta.8/powershell
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```powershell
PS > wh powershell                                                                                                  
wh : The term 'wh' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program.
Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
At line:1 char:1
+ wh powershell
+ ~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (wh:String) [], CommandNotFoundException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : CommandNotFoundException
```

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
Name                           Value                                                                                               
----                           -----                                                                                               
PSVersion                      6.0.0-beta.8                                                                                        
PSEdition                      Core                                                                                                
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-beta.8                                                                                       
OS                             Darwin 17.0.0 Darwin Kernel Version 17.0.0: Thu Aug 24 21:48:19 PDT 2017; root:xnu-4570.1.46~2/RE...
Platform                       Unix                                                                                                
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}                                                                             
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3                                                                                                 
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1                                                                                             
WSManStackVersion              3.0 
```

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body:
Likewise PowerShell aliases don't work in bash:

```
mark@posh-ubuntu:~$ powershell
PowerShell v6.0.0-beta.8
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

PS /home/mark> New-Alias -Name ech -Value /bin/echo
PS /home/mark> ech 1
1
PS /home/mark> bash
mark@posh-ubuntu:~$ ech 1
No command 'ech' found, did you mean:
 Command 'bch' from package 'bikeshed' (universe)
 Command 'echo' from package 'coreutils' (main)
 Command 'ecl' from package 'ecl' (universe)
 Command 'dch' from package 'devscripts' (main)
 Command 'ecc' from package 'ecere-dev' (universe)
 Command 'sch' from package 'scheme2c' (universe)
 Command 'ecm' from package 'gmp-ecm' (universe)
 Command 'ecs' from package 'ecere-dev' (universe)
 Command 'ecp' from package 'ecere-dev' (universe)
 Command 'ecj' from package 'ecj' (main)
ech: command not found
mark@posh-ubuntu:~$
```

I would not expect bash aliases to work in PowerShell and I would not expect PowerShell aliases to work in bash. Aliases are a convenience for the shell you are working in. 

Take this example going from bash to sh without any powershell involvement:

```
mark@posh-ubuntu:~$ alias wh='which'
mark@posh-ubuntu:~$ sh
$ wh
sh: 1: wh: not found
$
```

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body:
Bash aliases also don't work going from bash to bash:

```
mark@posh-ubuntu:~$ alias wh='which'
mark@posh-ubuntu:~$ wh powershell
/usr/bin/powershell
mark@posh-ubuntu:~$ bash
mark@posh-ubuntu:~$ wh powershell
wh: command not found
```

comments.author: thezim
comments.body:
Perfect sense and I agree even as I wrote the issue that they are their own shells.

> Bash aliases also don't work going from bash to bash:

While never passed they do work when they are in the `.bash_profile` which is the case for most Linux admins I know. By far 'll' (ls -la) is the most common. I just worry about the user experience once an admin drops to PowerShell.

comments.author: markekraus
comments.body:
> While never passed they do work when they are in the `.bash_profile`

Which is also true of PowerShell aliases in your `$profile` when you launch PowerShell

I think it's important to remember that PowerShell isn't something you use *under* bash, but something you use *in place of* bash. PowerShell is a shell just like bash and tsc. tsc doesn't use bash aliases, and bash doesn't use tsc aliases so there shouldn't be any expectation for PowerShell to use bash or tsc aliases nor for tsc or bash to use PowerShell aliases. Ideally, you would ssh to a system and never even touch bash, it would be PowerShell on the client side and server side. You can set your default shell in /etc/passwd to /usr/bin/powershell  on both client and server and never see bash again if you wanted.

> I just worry about the user experience once an admin drops to PowerShell.

I don't think that's an issue at all. Most Linux admins I've been exposed to understand concept of shells and understand that many things don't cross the shell wall.

title: Bash aliases do not work in PowerShell.
